awd_abstract_narration:
Massasoit Community College will develop the "STEM Scholars Associates" project, to provide annual scholarships for twenty low-income, academically talented students pursuing associate degrees in STEM disciplines. By leveraging scholarships with structured activities designed to increase academic success and workplace readiness, this project aims to increase the number of qualified STEM professionals prepared to address the challenges of the 21st century.

The goal of the "STEM Scholars Associates" project is to increase the number of low-income students who complete associate degrees and enter the STEM workforce either directly or after transferring to a baccalaureate-granting institution. In addition to scholarship assistance, this program will provide students with evidence-based curricular and co-curricular experiences focused on improving academic performance and confidence, building professional aptitude and reasoning abilities, and establishing a community of peers. Trained faculty mentors will help students explore career goals and ensure that they remain on track to degree completion and transfer. Industry partners will engage in a career speaker series and provide students with internship opportunities. Scholarship recipients will also have the opportunity to engage in on-campus research to build skills in critical thinking, problem solving, and workplace readiness. Carrying out this project will also provide insights into the conditions under which such curricular and co-curricular activities prove effective.

por.por_cntn:
Massasoit STEM: Deployment of NSF S-STEM Award

Our goal is to help students understand the connection between what they are doing now and what they want to be doing in the future. We want students to view academic progress not as the accumulation of credit hours, but as an opportunity to develop the core strengths, abilities and habits that will serve them throughout their professional lives. Funds awarded through the NSF S S-STEM Program provided scholarships for 62 separate students do averaged slightly over 2 semesterly awards of peace. These awards went directly to students and accounted for 60% of awarded money. These direct student aid scholarships had an obvious and instant effect on students, who Had more opportunity to study and engage in Co curricular activities such as the ones provided by the remainder of the NSF award. Grant funds were used to develop the following program.

 

Structure of Massasoit STEM

 

Every student at Massasoit who is pursuing a STEM degree is encouraged to opt into our program in the way that fits their schedule, interests or comfort level. There are three basic options:

  • Case Managed STEM Students: STEM staff and faculty meet with students, offer anytime-STEM advising, evaluate each completion plan, and generally keep an eye on the student. This is a great stepping stone for the other more intense and engaging options below.
  • STEM Scholars: An online non-credit course focused on STEM preparedness, basic soft-skills, and STEM career exploration. This is the home of the STEM speaker series.
  • Paid Research Internships: Massasoit offers intense paid internships within our native pollinator research program. Participants can remain employed for the duration of their time at Massasoit and gain both hard and soft skills far beyond their classroom peers. This is a real job that gives students a work history on their resume!

STEM Community at Massasoit:  

The Massasoit STEM community is a team of faculty, staff, and students who work together toward our mission of preparing students for whatever comes next. Not every student chooses to be an active participant in our program, but they can still benefit from our programs in many ways. For those that have the opportunity to fully engage, the experience can be transformational.

Alumni: The Massasoit STEM team works hard to stay in touch with and track the success of our program alumni. One of the most effective tools in the program is our ability to hire previous STEM Research Interns who are either working on, or have completed their bachelor’s degree. Keeping track of the alumni lets us know that the program is working. About 10 percent of the research students from the last five years are now either in medical school or graduate school, compared to the average community college bachelor’s degree success being about 10 percent (ref).

Paid Interns: The paid internship program is the heart and soul of Massasoit STEM. We employ between 15 and 20 research students year-round in support of our native pollinator research program. Research students work around 10 hours per week in the regular semesters and up to 30 hours per week in the summer. They are responsible for all aspects of the ongoing research, including fieldwork, sample processing, native bee preservation and identification, database management, and statistical analysis. As part of the program, students learn to evaluate the published scientific literature, give a scientific lecture, and even have the opportunity to present a poster at the Ecological Society of America annual meeting.

Research students also meet for the weekly Journal Club where they learn to present and lead a discussion about a peer-reviewed scientific journal article. This is a critical part of their training, and it guides the pollinator research program.

STEM Scholars: Students who don’t have the time or might not be ready for the challenge of a research internship, the STEM Scholars free online class provides a great opportunity to be an active member of the Massasoit STEM community. The course provides soft skills training and career exploration and adds a dose of STEM-world reality into their academic journey. As our alumni finish their education and see professional success, they are becoming routine speakers in the STEM Scholars Speaker Series, which is part of this program.

Case-Managed STEM Students: There are lots of hardworking and dedicated STEM students who don’t have time to add anything major to their already busy schedules. These students can join the STEM Success Program to be part of the Massasoit STEM community with minimal time commitment. They also have two short meetings per semester with the STEM Advisors’ Team. The STEM case manager keeps track of their progress and looks out for missteps or signs of trouble. These students have anytime access to a STEM advisor and are on the distribution list for important information and opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: Michael G Bankson
